title: Europa League last - 16 draw : The rules explained plus date , time and how to follow
body_text:
Manchester United ensured they would be joining Arsenal in the Europa League last 16 draw with a victory against Barcelona in a pulsating tie.
Erik ten Hag’s side had to come from behind in both legs to secure passage to the next round.
Marcus Rashford was the star at Camp Nou while a sublime team performance in the second half at Old Trafford saw them into the next round.
Advertisement
They, along with seven other teams, joined the other eight sides already in the hat for the last 16.
But, hen do they find out their last 16 opponents? And what are the rules of the draw?
GO DEEPER
This week was a glimpse of what a Super League world might look like
When is the draw?
The draw takes place on Friday, February 24 at 11am GMT (12pm CET, 6am EST, 3am PT).
It will be held at the House of European Football in Nyon, Switzerland.
The draw for the Europa Conference League last 16 will be held on Friday as well — that one is taking place an hour later at 12pm GMT (1pm CET, 7am EST, 4am PT).
How to follow the draw
UEFA will be live streaming the last 16 draw on their website (this link will become live closer to the event).
In the UK, BT Sport will be showing the draws for both competitions live.
If you are unable to watch the last 16 draw, we would love you to follow the updates as they happen from Nyon in our live blog, which will include snap analysis from our team of award-winning writers.
Which clubs are in the last 16 draw?
The Europa League can be a little bit confusing, especially compared to the Champions League.
The eight group winners progressed directly into the last 16 before the World Cup while all the runners up had to go into the knockout stage play-off round.
In that round, they were each drawn against one of the teams that finished third in their Champions League groups and dropped into the Europa League.
The eight Europa League group winners that will be in Friday’s draw are:
- Arsenal (England)
- Fenerbahce (Turkey)
- Real Betis (Spain)
- Union Saint-Gilloise (Belgium)
- Real Sociedad (Spain)
- Feyenoord (Netherlands)
- Freiburg (Germany)
- Ferencvaros (Hungary)
Meanwhile, the eight teams that prevailed in the play-off round are as follows.
- Juventus (Italy)
- Sevilla (Spain)
- Bayer Leverkusen (Germany)
- Sporting Lisbon (Portugal)
- Manchester United (England)
- Roma (Italy)
- Shakhtar Donetsk (Ukraine)
- Union Berlin (Germany)
How does the draw work?
The eight seeded teams will be the teams that won their Europa League groups, meaning the teams progressing from the play-off ties are unseeded.
The seeded teams will have the slight advantage of playing the second leg at home.
This is the final stage of the Europa League where teams from the same association cannot be pitted against each other.
Advertisement
So, Manchester United cannot face Arsenal in the last 16. Similarly, Real Betis and Real Sociedad will not be able to draw Sevilla while Freiburg will avoid Union Berlin.
From the quarter-final onwards, any of the teams can be drawn against each other.
The Europa League last 16 first legs will be played on March 9 — with the second legs being played a week later on March 16.
So, who can Arsenal and Manchester draw in the last 16?
Arsenal
- Bayer Leverkusen
- Juventus
- Roma
- Sevilla
- Shakhtar Donetsk
- Sporting Lisbon
- Union Berlin
Manchester United
- Fenerbahce
- Ferencvaros
- Feyenoord
- Freiburg
- Real Betis
- Real Sociedad
- Union Saint-Gilloise
